content.paragraph: This document outlines the business rules defined for the Bike project, based on the provided XML data.
content.heading: Overview
content.paragraph: This document details various business rules categorized by their nature. Many rules relate to configurable attributes, quality assurance, and content requirements.
content.heading: Business Rules
1. Data Validation & Configuration (Configurable Attributes)
content.paragraph: The following rules define valid values for configurable attributes within the Bike data set. These attributes are often used for filtering, categorization, and reporting.

list.listItem:
Threshold Interval Unit: Valid units of measurement for threshold intervals include:
Months Weeks Years Days Shop visits Auxiliary power unit change Wheel change kilometer

Attribute Source Type Code: Valid source types include:
fec sample

Attribute Source Criticality: Valid criticality levels include:
Evident, Safety Evident, operational Evident, Economic Hidden, Safety Hidden, Non-Safety

Task Code: Valid task codes include:
Detailed inspection (DET) Discard (DIS) Functional Check (FNC) General visual inspection (GVI) Lubrication (LUB) Operational check (OPC) Restoration (RST) Servicing (SVC) Visual check (VCK)

Limit Type: Valid limit types include:
Time between overhaul Hard time Since last maintenance Out time limit On condition Check maintenance Functional check

Origin of Equipment/Harness/Wire: Valid origins include:
Manufacturer Vendor Partner

content.heading: 2. Quality Assurance & Process
content.paragraph: EPWG Review & Approval: Bike data modules must be reviewed and approved by the EPWG (Engineering Product Working Group) before publication.
content.heading: 3. Content & Data Requirements
content.paragraph: Concept Sophistication Examples: The Bike data set must contain examples demonstrating the application of constructs and principles representing various levels of conceptual sophistication.
content.heading: Notes
content.paragraph: The categorization of some rules is based on interpretation of the provided data. It may be appropriate to re-categorize them based on further analysis or project needs. Rules pertaining to configurable attributes are considered data validation rules.
